name: Connes embedding problem
rephrased: Can complex infinite-dimensional systems (tracial von Neumann algebras) be faithfully mimicked by simpler finite systems (finite-dimensional matrices)?
implication_form: If a tracial von Neumann algebra exists, then it can be approximated by finite-dimensional matrices.
solved_by: The Connes Embedding Problem was shown to have a negative solution (i.e., not all tracial von Neumann algebras can be approximated by finite-dimensional matrices) as a corollary of the MIP*=RE result in 2020.
explained: The Connes Embedding Problem (CEP) is a fundamental question in operator algebras. It asks whether every tracial von Neumann algebra can be approximated in the sense of being embeddable or approximable by finite-dimensional matrix algebras (or their ultraproducts). In simpler terms, it questioned if the complex structure of infinite-dimensional tracial von Neumann algebras could be faithfully captured by simpler, finite-dimensional systems. This conjecture remained open for decades until it was resolved negatively in 2020 as a consequence of the groundbreaking result that MIP* = RE.
related_conjectures: QWEP (Quantization of the word problem for groups) problem
MIP* = RE (the result itself resolved CEP)
